docs.lead_paragraph: In a conference room behind the high gray walls, heavy steel latticework and thick bulletproof glass of the United States Embassy in San Salvador, one of the highest-ranking members of the diplomatic mission is offering his view of the facts of life to a group of American visitors. The delegation, which includes a Congressman, two entertainers active in human-rights causes and several others concerned about American policy, is angry; they have seen and spoken to political prisoners who say they've been tortured, Salvadoran officials who say they are doing their best and refugees who say little but suffer a lot. The diplomat is tired. This is the 17th delegation the embassy has shepherded through the Salvadoran labyrinth during the past few weeks. ''The semiannual precertification flying circus and hootenanny,'' another embassy official calls it. ''We take as a given that this country is a horror,'' the beleaguered diplomat tells his visitors. ''There are things here which are frightening and appalling to any sensitive human being. And those of us who work in this environment and see our friends killed, murdered, tortured by one group or another are not insensitive to these things.''

docs.lead_paragraph: This Wednesday, the Grammy Awards will celebrate their 25th anniversary in a live three-hour telecast on CBS from the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. While the Grammys, the record industry's answer to the Oscars, have yet to seize the public imagination the way its movie counterparts have done, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences (NARAS), which presents the awards, has steadily grown in stature since it was formed in 1957. Academy membership, open only to individuals creatively involved in making records, has risen from a few hundred to around 3,5OO. The first awards, presented in May 1959, counted only 28 categories as compared with 62 categories this year. These include crafts awards for engineering and packaging, as well as many special awards for children's, spoken word, ethnic and comedy records. And in keeping with current trends, there's even a video category. But over the years, the Grammys have drawn sharp criticism from within and without the record industry. Because the awards have always tended to slight rock music in favor of more middle-of-theroad pop, some rock acts have boycotted the awards. And the rock press, when it has paid any attention at all to the awards, has voiced contempt for NARAS's conservative tastes in rock and jazz.

docs.lead_paragraph: ELMSFORD ''THEY'RE PLAYING OUR SONG'' is a semiautobiographical minimusical. It contains two characters. In Charles Repole's staging at An Evening Dinner Theater, one of them is just right. Walter Bobbie as Vernon Gersch, the popular composer (supposedly fashioned after Marvin Hamlisch, who wrote the show's score) does not fit into the frenetic, neurotic male mold so often concocted by Neil Simon (who wrote the book). Mr. Bobbie is casual and disarming - a real original.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Hey, Yogi,'' Ken Griffey yelled to Yogi Berra, ''maybe you can help me. Where am I going to be this year?'' Berra, standing nearby in the Yankee clubhouse at Fort Lauderdale Stadium today, smiled and said, ''You got two gloves this year.'' ''Yeah,'' Griffey remarked with a shrug, ''I don't know where I'm going to be.'' A few minutes later, as the Yankees began filing out to the field for the start of the first workout of spring training, Griffey picked up a first baseman's glove and an outfielder's glove from the bench in front of his locker, shook his head and said, ''I don't know which glove to take out there. This is ridiculous.''

docs.lead_paragraph: There will be five official representatives of the United States Government accompanying Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip on their nine-day visit to the West Coast, which begins tomorrow. In the party will be Michael K. Deaver, the deputy chief of staff, and his wife, Carolyn; John J. Louis Jr., the United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James's, and his wife, Josephine, and a meticulously groomed woman whose job it is to make sure that all the diplomatic niceties are unobtrusively observed. The woman's name is Selwa Roosevelt and the sign over the door of her office at the State Department reads ''Chief of Protocol.'' Since her appointment last April, the 54-year-old Mrs. Roosevelt, who holds the rank of ambassador and is a successor to Leonore Annenberg, has been photographed greeting 27 kings, presidents, prime ministers and chancellors from countries as diverse as Costa Rica and Jordan, Iceland and India. But the flashbulbs catch only the icing on a complicated and multilayered cake. Her job touches every aspect of diplomatic relationships. ''We've been called the nannies of the diplomatic corps,'' she said in a recent interview that began in her spacious office and continued in her red-brick town house in Georgetown. ''We are the office of record for all the diplomatic corps, now about 6,000.''

docs.snippet: A venerated Indian leader, a man pretending to be a woman, and a lonesome visitor from outer space have taken the lion's share of the 1982 Academy Award nominations. As expected, ''Gandhi'' (11 nominations), ''Tootsie'' (10 nominations) and ''E.T....
docs.lead_paragraph: A venerated Indian leader, a man pretending to be a woman, and a lonesome visitor from outer space have taken the lion's share of the 1982 Academy Award nominations. As expected, ''Gandhi'' (11 nominations), ''Tootsie'' (10 nominations) and ''E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial'' (nine nominations) will be competing for most of the major awards, including best picture, best director, cinematography, film editing and best original screenplay. There were a few oddities in the list announced by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences this morning. However, except for what was regarded here as some shocking omissions among the foreignlanguage film nominees, the closest thing to a surprise were the strong showings of ''Victor/Victoria,'' Blake Edwards's farce about a woman masquerading as a man pretending to be a woman, which was in fourth place with seven nominations, and ''Das Boot,'' a West German movie about a U-boat crew during the last months of World War II, which tied for fifth place with six nominations. ''Missing,'' Costa-Gavras's movie about a father who searches for his son and discovers he has been killed by a repressive South American regime, and ''The Verdict,'' Sidney Lumet's film about an alcoholic lawyer's last desperate attempt to redeem himself, joined ''E.T.,'' ''Gandhi,'' and ''Tootsie'' as nominees for best picture.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sam Schulman, the owner of the Seattle SuperSonics, said yesterday that he would relish a strike by the National Basketball Players Association because it ''would enable us to return to normalcy.'' Schulman's remarks were in stark contrast to the stance of the National Basketball Association's leadership and most team owners, who have been reluctant to speak forcefully about the months-long sensitive negotiations for a collective bargaining agreement to replace the one that expired last June 1. The Seattle owner spoke in a telephone interview from his home in Los Angeles one day after Larry Fleisher, the union's general counsel, had suggested that the players might strike if there were no new agreement by April 1. ''I dare them to strike,'' Schulman said. ''The players are overpaid. A strike would enable us to return to normalcy and start all over again. Larry Fleisher has admitted to us that at least 10 teams are in financial trouble. I venture to say that there are more.''

docs.snippet: More than eight months after the expiration of its old contract with the National Basketball Association, the union representing the league's players set an April 1 deadline yesterday for agreement on a new one.   Larry Fleisher, the general couns...
docs.lead_paragraph: More than eight months after the expiration of its old contract with the National Basketball Association, the union representing the league's players set an April 1 deadline yesterday for agreement on a new one. Larry Fleisher, the general counsel of the National Basketball Players Association, did not characterize this as a strike deadline, but he did say that a walkout was among the options. ''If we don't have an agreement by then,'' Fleisher said, ''the players will take all the necessary action, including a strike, to protect the interests of all the players.'' The regular season ends April 17, and Fleisher acknowledged that the April 1 deadline was designed to pressure the league into a settlement before the start of the playoffs. The N.B.A. counts heavily on playoff revenue, and its contract with CBS, worth $22 million this season, calls for many of the playoff games to be televised.

docs.lead_paragraph: Federico Mompou may not be a composer whose name rings a bell with many American music followers, but his songs and piano music have a charm and distinction all their own and he is one of Spain's most cherished musical figures. His 90th birthday is fast approaching (he was born on April 10, 1893) and in anticipation of that anniversary a concert honoring Mompou was given at Alice Tully Hall last night. Organized and conducted by Max Bragado-Darman, a native of Spain who studied in this country at Oberlin College and the University of Michigan and who led youth and student orchestras in this country in the mid-70's, the concert enlisted the services of the Classic Chamber Orchestra (an ensemble made up largely of young American instrumentalists), the chorus of the University of Oviedo from Spain, and Pablo Elvira, the Puerto Rican baritone.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said Tuesday that Mickey Rooney would receive an honorary Oscar for ''50 years of versatility in a variety of memorable film performances'' at the April 11 presentations. The actor, who appeared in 124 films, was nominated four times for an Oscar but never won. Officials also said Walter Mirisch, producer of the Oscar-wining ''In the Heat of the Night,'' would receive the Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award.
